_prev_prog_3.Description: The Occidental Chemical Pedricktown PVC plant operates one covered process: the Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) Process. This process consists of interconnected equipment from the VCM Spheres to the VCM Charge System to the PVC Reactor System to the VCM Recovery System. All this equipment is considered to be operated within a single unit. For the purpose of providing focus and to breakdown tasks involved, the process is broken down into various segements on which separate PHA studies are conducted. The various elements of the Prevention Program mentioned here are common to all segments of this process and are applied equally. Several common type of safeguards such as lower explosion limit (LEL) detectors, deluge systems and alarms/interlocks are provided throughout this process. The exception as noted above is the timing of completion of the latest PHA studies, which are provided below by the systems studied: VCM Tank Farm completed in 11/2017, Polymerization Process (Poly) completed in 12/2014 and to be conducted in 2019, and the Ammonia Refrigeration System completed 11/2018.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: New Jersey Toxic Catastrophe Prevention Act Regulations N.J.A.C. 7:31

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The Oxy Vinyls facility at Pedricktown, New Jersey is a producer of PVC resin. Oxy Vinyls is wholly owned by Occidental Chemical (OxyChem) Corporation.  



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source (A? 68.155(a))



Oxy Vinyls has established a system for the safe operation of the processes at this facility that includes the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  One component of this system is a program to manage the risks of accidental releases at the Pedricktown PVC facility.  This program conforms to the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) regulation 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirement Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule), the requirements of OSHA 1910.119 and the requirements of New Jersey's Toxic Catastrophe Prevention Act (TCPA)RMP program.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMP plan requirement of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at the Pedricktown PVC facility.



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled (A? 68.155(b))



The Oxy Vinyls Pedricktown PVC facility consists of a single PVC resin production plant that is wholly owned by OxyChem.  OxyChem operates only the Oxy Vinyls Suspension PVC Resin plant at the site.  The facility handles two (2) substances that are regulated by the RMP rule.  These substances are as follows:







Vinyl Chloride Monomer



Anhydrous Ammonia





The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Specific Prevention Steps (A? 68.155(c))



The Oxy Vinyls Pedricktown PVC facility's prevention program has been prepared so that it conforms to both the OSHA Process Safety Management and the EPA Risk Management Plan regulations.  The program consists of the following elements:



Process Safety Information

Process Hazard Analysis

Operating Procedures

Training

Mechanical Integrity

Management of Change

Pr

e-Startup Review

Compliance Audits

Incident Investigation

Employee Participation

Key Procedures

Contractors



Each of the items listed above are documented and routinely reviewed for improvement.

Five-year Accident History (A? 68.155(d))



There were not any RMP accidents at this facility in the past 5 years.



Emergency Response Program (A? 68.155(e))



The Pedricktown PVC facility has established a written emergency response plan and maintains an emergency response team (ERT) trained in these emergency response procedures. The team is comprised of employees from OxyVinyls and two other co-located site companies, PolyOne and Lubrizol.  All plant personnel are trained in evacuation procedures and in-plant drills are conducted periodically.  The drills are used to test the response time of the Emergency Response Team, to test the plant employee accountability program, and to activate the plant's Emergency Operations Center (EOC).  In addition, the OxyVinyls Pedricktown PVC facility has developed a Special Situations Plan (SSP) which is a program designed for responding to emergencies that may have impacts beyond the immediate plant and is a supplement to the Emergency Response Plan.  The Special Situation Plan links the local response to the OxyChem Corporate Emergency Response Center located in Dallas, Texas.



The facility is a member of the Oldmans Township Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), which includes industrial and public entities.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety (A? 68.155(f))



The OxyVinyls Pedricktown PVC facility constantly works to improve the safety of the processes through annual reviews of our plant procedures, near misses and incident investigation programs, and a program soliciting safety and environmental suggestions from all employees. Specific changes include installation of additional process controls and enhancements related to modernization projects.
